comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/alimarante] Can't find much about the men. But here's a few lines on the cars: The Free State Army's Armoured Car Corps was established in September, 1922. Officer commanding was Capt. Joe Hyland. (He may or may not be in the picture). The corps had different armoured car types (including Lancia and Peerless cars), but the most notable was the Rolls-Royce. Nicknamed "the Whippet" in Ireland it was built on the "Silver Ghost" chassis, and had a turret mounted Vickers .303 water-cooled machine-gun. Although it's engine was liable to overheat unless the armoured radiator doors were left open, they were powerful and relatively quiet (important in the type of conflicts seen in the Civil War). It was common to give nicknames to cars. They were: ARR 1 'Tom Keogh' (renamed from 'Danny Boy' after Col.Comdt. Keogh was killed in 1922) ARR 2 'Sliabh no mBan' ARR 3 'Fighting Second' ARR 4 'The Baby' ARR 5 'The Manager' ARR 6 'Custom House' ARR 7 'Moneygall' ARR 8 'The Big Fellow' ARR 9 'Ex-Mutineer' ARR 10 'Flying Fifty' ARR 11 'Kilmichael' ARR 12 'Knockananna' ARR 14 'The High Chief' (Seemingly there was no ARR 13 for superstitious reasons) I couldn't find a summary of the history of ARR 8, but ARR 3 (on the right of the pic) took part in the fighting for Dublin in June/July of 1922 and was active from the very start of the Irish civil war. It was noted to be on patrol in the area of the Four courts in May 1922. The fighting 2nd went through the early months of the war with its original British Crown forces registration until it was appointed its ARR number in December 1922. Anti-treaty forces also had a few (improvised) armored cars. The 'Queen of the West' was constructed in Mayo and 'The River Lee' was constructed in Cork. Further reading: * Details of ARR2: www.curragh.info/articles/silabhnamban.htm * Peter Leslie, "Armoured Cars in Ireland [Pt.1]" Military Modelling (May 1980) * Duggan, John P. A History of the Irish Army. (Dublin: Gill and Macmillan, 1991).

comment.author: 45785863@N06
comment._content:
I think I seen that photo in the Cork examiner 10,7,1922 page 3 (not sure mite be aswell to check it again in the Kildare Street library archive microfilm). both cars were in action in Dublin from the very start of the civil war and were photo several times in the area of the Four Courts and O Connell street, even their reg numbers are very similar "1043 CK" and "1093 CK".  The reg numbers of all the Rolls changed very late in 1922 to "ARR" (Armoured Rolls Royce) .  
There was in fact 14 "1920 pattern Rolls Royce" armoured cars handed over to the Irish National army by the departing British, "The Ballinalee" was one of the early handovers, but fell into the hands of the IRA in July of 1922 untill September 1922 at which point it was totally destroyed by a salvo from a national army 18pdr field gun in Co Sligo and was not around when the ARR numbers were issued. 
A secound Rolls Royce "the muinteer" also fell into the hands of the IRA and served with distinction at the Four Courts. It was later recaptured by the National army and renamed the "ex mutineer".  
In Irish army service the Rolls armoured cars were nicked named "Whippets"

There are two survivors of the original Irish ARRs .  ARR1 is with a private collector in the UK and ARR2 is on show in the Curragh camp Co Kildare, as has already been posted by guliolopez

comment.author: 54664152@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/20727502@N00] Thanks for all the information. Could you help me to better understand the meaning of these names: ARR 2 'Sliabh no mBan' ARR 6 'Custom House' ARR 7 'Moneygall' ARR 11 'Kilmichael' ARR 12 'Knockananna' 'Sliabh no mBan notwithstanding, as an American, I am curious :Custom House is not a term we use here...not to mention Knockanana ! They are interesting nicknames... Thanks!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/54664152@N02] Ok, most are place names - Moneygall, Kilmichael, Knockananna... For example, Sliabh na mBan in the Irish language means Mountain of the Women (in Co. Tipperary). A custom house was a building where government officials processed imports and exports, so always near a port or on quays... Hope that helps?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
